intro: Scirpus melanocarpus, commonly known as black fruit sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant belonging to the Cyperaceae family. It is characterized by its triangular, grass-like stems and dark purple to black berries that develop at the base of the plant. Native to wetlands and marshy areas in North America, it thrives in moist, nutrient-rich soils. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and is often found in shallow water or along the edges of ponds and lakes. Its distinctive appearance makes it a valuable component of wetland ecosystems, providing habitat and food for various wildlife species.
